projects.name: Beaded Buttons

tools.name: paper squares
tools.purpose: marking the beginning of each round

steps.instruction: Start by threading the beads onto the crochet yarn. The instructions all have a diagram indicating the bead sequence. A special bead-threading needle consisting of two wires that are joined together at the ends is ideal. The wires can be pulled apart and the yarn threaded with ease. These needles are very thin, which means that tiny rocailles (seed beads, approximately 2mm (1/16 in) diameter) can also be used. As the holes in some beads will invariably be too small for the needle and thread to fit through, only thread a few beads at a time, and then push them onto the yarn.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a bead-threading needle with several small beads threaded onto it, with more beads in a small container.

steps.instruction: It is a good idea to mark the beginning of each round with a little piece of paper. Cut out some small paper squares and push a needle through the middle. The beads are crocheted in the opposite order to that on the thread. This means that the last bead to be threaded is the first one to be crocheted. In the diagrams (see page 11), the first bead to be threaded is identified by the number 1.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a length of yarn with beads threaded onto it, secured at intervals by small green paper squares with a needle pushed through them.

steps.instruction: Once all the beads have been threaded, work five chain stitches and join in a circle with one slip stitch. Crochet tightly so that the beads are close together.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand holding a crochet hook with a loop of yarn and beads, forming the beginning of a circle.

tips: With transparent beads, the colour of the crochet yarn will shine through, changing the colour of the beads. This can be seen quite clearly in the furniture knobs on page 14.
projects.finished_product_description: Sparkling, elegant, fabulously bright and unique beaded buttons.

diagram_descriptions: A large, vibrant photograph showcasing a variety of crocheted beaded buttons in different shapes, sizes, and color combinations, arranged on a white background. Some are spherical, others are cylindrical or flat. The beads are small and tightly crocheted, creating intricate patterns and textures. The overall impression is one of colorful and detailed craftsmanship.

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Buttons

steps.instruction: Continue crocheting the beads. These are single crochet stitches (UK double crochet) with beads threaded onto the yarn. Insert the hook into the back loop of the next stitch and push the first bead onto your work. Pull the yarn behind the bead and through the stitch so you have two loops on the hook. Then pull the yarn through the two loops on the hook.
steps.technique: single crochet (UK double crochet) with beads
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a crochet hook with yarn and beads, showing the process of adding a beaded stitch.

steps.instruction: In the first round, work one bead stitch into each chain stitch; at the end of the round the beads will form a circle. In the second round, work two and three bead stitches alternately into each stitch of the previous round = twelve stitches/beads.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a partially crocheted circle with beads, indicating the formation of a circle.

steps.instruction: The instructions for each button will tell you whether to work in spirals or rounds. With spirals there is no clear transition between the rounds; simply continue working bead stitches. If the sequence of beads makes it impossible to see the transition, use a different colour thread to mark the variation.

If the pattern consists of completed rounds, the round is finished with one slip stitch into the first stitch of the round. The picture shows the free final stitch of the previous round (black arrow), the slip stitch finishing the previous round (blue arrow), the chain stitch at the transition between the rows (green arrow) and the first stitch of this round into which the slip stitch is crocheted to end the round (red arrow).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a crocheted piece showing different stitches and arrows indicating the end of a round and the start of a new one. Arrows point to the final stitch, slip stitch, chain stitch, and the first stitch of the new round.

steps.instruction: Then move on to the next round with one chain stitch, and crochet the first bead stitch into the first stitch of the previous round that also has the slip stitch (when increasing, also work two bead stitches at the beginning of the round).
steps.visual_description: Image showing a crocheted piece in progress, with a crochet hook working on a new round.

steps.instruction: Once you have worked all of the beads, secure the beginning of the thread and place the shank button on the back of the bead surface so that the stitch loops are against the outer edge of the button. Then continue working in spirals, decreasing two single crochet (UK double crochet) together.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a shank button being placed on the back of a crocheted beaded piece, with the crochet hook working on the edge.

steps.instruction: Insert the hook in the first stitch, draw one loop through, insert in the second stitch, and draw through another loop so you have three loops on the hook. Draw the yarn through all three loops together.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a crochet hook with three loops on it, demonstrating the process of decreasing stitches.

steps.instruction: Continue crocheting until the shank button is entirely covered.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a finished crocheted beaded button, with the shank button completely covered.

tips: If the sequence of beads makes it impossible to see the transition, use a different colour thread to mark the variation.
projects.finished_product_description: A crocheted button covered in beads, with a shank button on the back.

diagram_descriptions: Threading diagram for button A: Shows a sequence of beads to be threaded for button A, arranged in rows representing rounds. Each row indicates the number of beads and their colors (pink, brown). Some rows are repeated 3x. The numbers 5, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36 indicate the number of stitches/beads in that round.

Threading diagram for button B: Similar to diagram A, but with a different sequence of beads (blue, brown, pink) for button B. Each row indicates the number of beads and their colors. Some rows are repeated 3x. The numbers 5, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36 indicate the number of stitches/beads in that round.
Image A: A finished crocheted beaded button, predominantly pink and brown.
Image B: A finished crocheted beaded button, predominantly blue and transparent beads with some brown.

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Buttons

materials.quantity: 6 colours for button A, 2 colours for button B, 5 colours for button C

steps.instruction: Thread the beads as shown in the diagram. For button A, thread the recurring bead sequences in the quantity shown. The diagrams for buttons B and C show all the beads. Crochet the buttons in spirals (see page 10). The diagram for button A shows where to increase from the 3rd round on.
steps.visual_description: Diagrams for threading beads for buttons A, B, and C.

steps.instruction: Thread the bead sequences as shown in the diagram and in the given quantities.
steps.visual_description: Diagrams for threading beads for buttons A, B, and C.

steps.instruction: Work five chain stitches and join in a ring with a slip stitch.

Crochet buttons A and B in rounds, button C in spirals (see pages 10-11). In the second round, work two and three bead stitches alternately into each stitch of the previous round = 12 stitches. All other increases are indicated in the diagram.
steps.visual_description: Diagrams for threading beads for buttons A, B, and C, showing stitch counts and increases.

projects.finished_product_description: Three crocheted beaded buttons (A, B, and C) with different bead patterns and colors.

diagram_descriptions: Photo showing three finished crocheted beaded buttons labeled A, B, and C.
Threading diagram for button A, showing rows of beads to be threaded onto a needle, with stitch counts and repeat indicators.
Threading diagram for button B, showing rows of beads to be threaded onto a needle, with stitch counts and repeat indicators.
Threading diagram for button C, showing rows of beads to be threaded onto a needle, with stitch counts and repeat indicators.
Symbols key explaining the meaning of different colored beads and stitch notations (e.g., number of beads in a round, increase stitches).

projects.name: Furniture Knobs

materials.details: screws to suit the thickness of the wood

steps.instruction: Thread the beads as shown in the threading diagram.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing rows of beads and symbols indicating bead colors and stitch counts for each round, starting with 5 beads in the first round and increasing to 36 beads in the sixth round. The diagram also shows a needle and thread.

steps.instruction: Work five chain stitches and join with a slip stitch to make a ring.
steps.visual_description: A small crocheted ring formed by 5 chain stitches.

steps.instruction: Continue working in spirals.
steps.visual_description: The crocheted ring is being worked into, forming a spiral shape.

steps.instruction: Push the washers onto the sleeve and place both on the back of the bead surface in place of the shank button.
steps.visual_description: A washer being threaded onto a screw sleeve, and then placed onto the back of a crocheted bead structure.

steps.instruction: Continue working in spirals as for the button, decreasing two stitches each round, until the last few stitches are tight around the sleeve.
steps.visual_description: The crocheted bead structure is being worked around the washer and sleeve assembly, with decreases being made to create a tight fit.

tips: Using light or dark yarn will create an entirely different look with transparent beads.
Knob A is crocheted in white yarn, knob B in white on the inside and blue on the outside, and knob C all in blue yarn.
The bead colours are the same on all three knobs.
projects.finished_product_description: Crocheted beaded furniture knobs that are compact and durable.

diagram_descriptions: A threading diagram showing rows of beads with symbols indicating colors (light blue, turquoise, dark blue) and stitch counts per round (5, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36). Each row is labeled with '3x' indicating a repeat, except for the first row. A needle and thread are shown, with a knot at the end of the thread.

Symbols key explaining the bead colors (light blue transparent, turquoise transparent, dark blue transparent), the meaning of '18' as the number of beads in a round, and the symbol for working 2 bead stitches into 1 stitch in the previous round (= increase 1).

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Buttons

steps.instruction: Thread the beads in accordance with the instructions.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and thread, with several small green beads threaded onto the thread.

steps.instruction: Work three bead stitches into a loop of thread (see page 62). Be particularly careful with the first stitch to make sure the bead is on the outside.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and thread, with a small loop of thread and several beads being worked into a crochet stitch. A small bead is visible on the outside of the stitch.

steps.instruction: Continue working spiral rounds in bead stitches and increase as you work. Insert the hook in the first of the three stitches (see white arrow) and work three bead stitches into this stitch. Work three bead stitches into each of the remaining two stitches = nine stitches.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and thread, working into a small crocheted piece with beads. A white arrow points to the first stitch where new stitches are being worked. The piece is starting to form a rounded shape.

steps.instruction: Now carefully tighten the loop of thread.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand tightening a loop of thread around a small crocheted piece with beads.

steps.instruction: To mark the end of one round and beginning of the next, pull a piece of thread in a different colour through at the beginning of the new round.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and thread, with a contrasting colored thread being pulled through the beginning of a new round of crochet stitches.

steps.instruction: Bead with shank: push the rivet pin into a large bead. Trim the end of the wire to 1.5cm (½in) with the wire cutters, then fold over with some pliers and push the end of the wire into the hole.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a large bead with a rivet pin inserted. Wire cutters and pliers are also visible, suggesting the wire is being trimmed and bent.

steps.instruction: Continue working as described in the instructions. Then push the bead and shank into the crochet and start to decrease. Insert the needle in the next stitch, push one bead onto the crochet work, and draw through one loop. Insert the hook in the next stitch, slide another bead onto the work and draw a loop through so that you have three loops on your hook. Yarn around the hook and draw through all three loops on the hook.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and thread, working on a crocheted piece with a large bead shank. Beads are being added and stitches are being decreased. Three loops are visible on the crochet hook.

steps.instruction: Decreasing will close the stitches around the shank. The bead is worked into your crochet.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a finished crocheted beaded button with a large central bead and a shank. The decreasing stitches are visible, closing the fabric around the shank.

tips: The smaller these are and the more there are of them, the better: a loop fastening with sparkling ball buttons is a perfect highlight on any item of clothing.
projects.finished_product_description: Small, spherical buttons made of crochet and beads, designed to be used as fastenings on clothing.

diagram_descriptions: A large photograph on the right side of the page shows several finished crocheted beaded buttons attached to a textured, light blue fabric. The buttons are spherical and made of small, translucent green beads, with a larger pearl-like bead visible in some of them. They are attached with a loop of light blue thread or yarn.

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Buttons
tips: Mark the beginning of each round with a small piece of paper.
Once threaded, approximately 60-65 beads measure about 10cm (4in).
For slightly rounded buttons, one additional row may be needed.
Thread beads of the same colour, each round in a different colour, or as per the diagrams for buttons C and D.
You can achieve terrific results with random combinations of buttons.
Before working the back, you might want to sew one bead into the middle of the button with the starting thread, and then secure the thread.
Stuff the button with wadding/batting and shape it into a semi-sphere.
Make the back.
projects.finished_product_description: Handmade crocheted beaded buttons in various sizes and colors.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram A shows a threading pattern for a button, with rows of beads indicated by circles and squares, and numbers indicating bead counts per round (5, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36, 36, 36). It also shows a needle with thread passing through the beads.
Diagram B shows a close-up of a crocheted beaded button with a spiral pattern of blue, green, and white beads.

Diagram C shows a threading diagram for button C, with rows of beads indicated by circles and squares, and numbers indicating bead counts per round (5, 12, 18, 24, 24, 24). It also shows a needle with thread passing through the beads.

Diagram D shows a threading diagram for button D, with rows of beads indicated by circles and squares, and numbers indicating bead counts per round (5, 12, 18, 24, 24, 24). It also shows a needle with thread passing through the beads.
A visual representation of various crocheted beaded buttons in different sizes and color combinations, labeled A, B, C, and D.
A visual representation of a plain fabric button with a textured surface, with a measurement line indicating 27mm (1in) diameter.
A visual representation of a plain fabric button with a textured surface, with a measurement line indicating 22mm (3/4in) diameter.
A visual representation of a plain fabric button with a textured surface, with a measurement line indicating 16mm (5/8in) diameter.
A visual representation of a plain fabric button with a textured surface, with a measurement line indicating 12mm (1/2in) diameter.

A key for symbols used in the threading diagrams, indicating colors and bead types (white opaque, light turquoise opaque, turquoise transparent, light green transparent, green transparent, anthracite opaque).

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Squares

steps.instruction: Thread the beads in accordance with the instructions. Work eight chain stitches, then slip stitch into the first chain to make a ring and crochet one bead stitch into each stitch. End the round with one slip stitch in the first stitch of the round. Chain one stitch, then continue working the next round. Work the first bead stitch of the next round into the slip stitch at the end of the round, i.e. into the first stitch of the previous round. Work the following rows in the same way. The diagonal stitch (green arrow) is the slip stitch at the end of the last row. The chain stitch to change rows (red arrow) is worked over it. The slip stitch at the end of the row (white arrow) is worked into the first stitch of the previous row.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a crochet hook working with blue yarn and beads, with arrows indicating stitches. Image 2 shows a close-up of a crochet hook working a bead stitch into a previous stitch. Image 3 shows a partially completed beaded square.

steps.instruction: At the corners, work three bead stitches into the corner stitches in the previous round. Unless indicated otherwise in the threading diagram, in row two work three bead stitches into every second stitch, in row three into every fourth stitch, in row five into every sixth stitch etc.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing how to increase at the corners of the square.

steps.instruction: Increasing at the corners creates a square. With the larger buttons that are crocheted using shank buttons measuring approximately 22 x 22mm (¾ x ¾in), in the last round work two bead stitches into the corner stitches instead of three so that the beads lie firmly against the crochet. Then work one round of single crochets (UK double crochets) without beads and without increasing. Secure the beginning of the thread and sew one bead into the middle of the button. Work the back as for the round buttons (see page 11).
steps.visual_description: Image shows a finished beaded square button with a shank button backing.

tips: If you have threaded too many beads or used one in the wrong colour, you can crush it with pliers to remove it. Push a needle through the bead, to protect the yarn and so as not to cut it with the broken bead. Put some paper towel around the pliers and the bead to catch splinters.
If a bead is missing, work a single crochet (UK double crochet) in that space and sew the matching bead onto the spare stitch at the end.
projects.finished_product_description: Small crocheted beaded squares, some of which are buttons with shank backs.

diagram_descriptions: Image 1 shows a crochet hook working with blue yarn and beads, with arrows indicating stitches.
Image 2 shows a close-up of a crochet hook working a bead stitch into a previous stitch.
Image 3 shows a partially completed beaded square.
Diagram showing how to increase at the corners of the square.
Image shows a finished beaded square button with a shank button backing.
Image shows a needle threading a single blue bead onto a blue thread, with scissors nearby.
Close-up of a hand holding pliers to crush a bead.

projects.name: Cylinders

materials.color: 4-6 colours for button A, 7 colours for button B, 9 colours for button C

steps.instruction: Bend the tiny hook eyes so they stand out at an angle of 90° using flat-nose pliers to grip the eye (the rounded bent part).
steps.visual_description: Close-up image of hands using two pairs of pliers to bend a small metal hook eye.

steps.instruction: Squeeze the neck of the eye gently to make it easier to work it into the crochet.
steps.visual_description: Close-up image of hands using pliers to gently squeeze the neck of a metal hook eye.

steps.instruction: Crochet as far as the marked place, then chain one and push the hook eye into the crochet with the large wire hoop facing outward. Miss the next stitch (the hook eye will fill this gap), then continue working bead stitches as before.
steps.visual_description: Close-up image of a crochet hook working with red beads and a red thread, with a metal hook eye being incorporated into the crochet work.

steps.instruction: In the next round, again work one bead stitch into the chain so that the number of stitches remains the same in each round. Continue crocheting according to the instructions. When you decrease, carefully stuff the button with wadding/batting (if instructed) without moving the hook eye on the inside.
steps.visual_description: Close-up image of a crochet hook working with red beads and a red thread, showing the button being stuffed with wadding.

tips: If you increase fewer stitches, you will end up with a cylinder rather than a circle or square.
You can make necklaces and bracelets from cylinders – and you can also make toggle fastenings.
projects.finished_product_description: Crocheted beaded buttons that can be used as toggle fastenings or incorporated into jewelry like necklaces and bracelets.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the threading pattern for button B, with rows numbered 8, 16, 24, 32, 40, and 44, and beads represented by colored circles and crosses.
Diagram showing the threading pattern for button C, with rows numbered 8, 16, 24, 32, 40, and 44, and beads represented by colored circles and crosses.
Illustration of a needle and thread with beads, indicating the threading process for the buttons.
Key showing symbols for different bead colors and types (opaque and transparent) and a symbol for working multiple stitches into a corner.
Image 1: Close-up of hands using two pairs of pliers to bend a small metal hook eye.
Image 2: Close-up of hands using pliers to gently squeeze the neck of a metal hook eye.
Image 3: Close-up of a crochet hook working with red beads and a red thread, with a metal hook eye being incorporated into the crochet work.
Image 4: Close-up of a crochet hook working with red beads and a red thread, showing the button being stuffed with wadding.

projects.name: Crocheted Beaded Buttons

steps.instruction: For the striped button, crochet the cylinder with nine stitches to a round. For the striped pattern, use ten beads per repeat to create diagonal stripes.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a striped beaded button.

steps.instruction: Start by threading four light red/lilac beads, then forty-seven beads – alternating one light red/dark red or black/lilac bead. Later on, work in the hook eye instead of the next dark red/lilac bead. Mark this place with a piece of paper (see page 8). Then start again with light red/black, and thread another forty-eight beads in alternating colours plus four light red/lilac beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a striped beaded button.

steps.instruction: To start, crochet four bead stitches in a loop of thread (see pages 16 and 62). In the next round, work two bead stitches three times and three bead stitches once into each stitch in the previous round = nine beads. Continue in spirals without increasing to the marked place. Work in the hook eye (see page 23) and continue crocheting until only thirteen beads are left on the thread. In the next round, decrease two bead stitches together three times and three bead stitches together once = four stitches. Work one round with four bead stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a striped beaded button.

steps.instruction: For the plain button, thread fifty-one beads, mark the place for the eye, and thread another fifty-two beads. Crochet the button as described above.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a plain beaded button.

steps.instruction: For the beginning, thread twenty-six beads in anthracite, then thread five repeats of eighteen stitches for the striped pattern (the diagram shows one repeat), and insert a paper marker after seventeen beads. For the next (sixth) repeat, replace the first bead with the marker for the hook eye, and start with two red beads. Repeat this to the end and thread four more repeats, then twenty-six beads in anthracite.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button with a striped pattern.

steps.instruction: Start by crocheting four bead stitches in a loop (see pages 16 and 62). In the next round, crochet three bead stitches three times and two bead stitches once into each stitch in the previous round = eleven beads. Crochet eleven bead stitches in round three. In the following round, crochet two bead stitches into the first and then every other stitch = seventeen beads. Continue crocheting in spirals without increasing as far as the marker.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: Work in the hook eye (see page 23) and continue to the next marker. In the following round, work the first and second and then every second and third bead stitch together to decrease = 11 stitches. Stuff the button with wadding/batting. Work one round in bead stitches and in the following round decrease three stitches together three times and two bead stitches together once = four stitches. If required, add a little more wadding/batting when you decrease. Work one more round of four bead stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: Thread 143 beads (approximately 22cm / 8¾in). Crochet three bead stitches into a loop (see pages 16 and 62). Mark the beginning of the round with different coloured thread.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 2nd round: work two bead stitches into every stitch = 6 beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 3rd round: work two bead stitches into second every stitch = 9 beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 4th round: work two bead stitches into every third stitch = 12 beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 5th round: work two bead stitches into every fourth stitch = 15 beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 6th round: work two bead stitches into every fifth stitch = 18 beads.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 7th round: nine bead stitches, crochet in hook eye (see page 23), one chain to skip one stitch, eight bead stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 8th round: decrease every 5th and 6th bead stitch together = 15 stitches (see page 23).
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 9th round: decrease every fourth and fifth bead stitch together = 12 stitches. Stuff the button with wadding/batting, and add a little more over the following rows as required.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 10th round: decrease every third and fourth bead stitch together = 9 stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 11th round: decrease every second and third bead stitch together = 6 stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 12th round: decrease two bead stitches together = 3 stitches.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: 13th round: work three slip stitches, then work in one bead as for the bead stitches in single crochet (UK double).
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: The diagram shows the beads that need to be threaded for one repeat. Thread twenty-four repeats, omitting the last bead in the twelfth repeat and instead mark the place for the hook eye with a piece of paper.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a threading pattern for beads.

steps.instruction: Work twelve chain stitches and join with a slip stitch. Continue working bead stitches in spirals, keeping an eye on the height of the cylinder: after twelve repeats, the work should measure about 25mm (1in) at the marker, i.e. halfway up the book screw. Work the hook eye at the marker (see page 23). Continue working in spirals. Work the last bead in with one slip stitch, then cut off the thread, draw through and secure.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button.

steps.instruction: Push the sleeve nut of the book screw into the crocheted piece and secure on the other side with the screw.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a beaded button with a book screw.

tips: The buttons look better if they are crocheted quite tightly.
projects.finished_product_description: A variety of crocheted beaded buttons in different patterns and colors.

Diagram showing a beaded button with a purple color, numbered 3.
Diagram showing a beaded button with a red and gold striped pattern, numbered 4.
Diagram showing three beaded buttons: one red/brown striped, one purple, and one black/purple striped, numbered 1.

Threading diagram for one repeat of 18 beads, showing a sequence of orange, black, purple, red, and black beads, with a key for bead colors: orange (transparent), red (transparent), lilac (transparent), anthracite (opaque).

Threading diagram for one repeat of thirteen beads, showing a sequence of orange, red, and gold beads, with a key for bead colors: orange (transparent), dark red (transparent), light red (transparent), gold (opaque).

projects.name: Painted & Embroidered Buttons

tools.name: sewing machine
tools.purpose: embroidering circles, spirals and little boxes

steps.instruction: Set the fabric in an embroidery frame. Start with the lighter colours, then apply the darker ones. Colour an area that is a little bigger than the chosen button size. This will prevent any unwanted white areas around the edge of the button. Take the fabric out of the embroidery frame and iron on the wrong side, placing a piece of baking parchment under the fabric to protect your ironing board.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a red crayon or marker, coloring a circular piece of white fabric stretched in an embroidery hoop. The fabric has a pre-drawn spiral design in yellow and red. Another embroidery hoop with fabric is visible to the right, also with a pre-drawn design.

steps.instruction: Set the fabric in the frame with embroidery fleece. If you put the fabric in the frame the wrong way round with the larger ring under the fabric and the small one on top, you can use an ordinary embroidery frame. Depending on the size of the fabric, you can also work with just the embroidery fleece or embroidery foil without a frame. Lower or cover the feed dogs (refer to the instructions for your machine) and insert an embroidery or quilting foot. Loosen the upper thread slightly so that the lower thread does not show on the front. Choose the lower thread in the matching colour, just to be on the safe side. Sewing machine embroidery thread is best: it is a little thicker and shinier than normal sewing thread, and creates brighter results. With the fabric in the embroidery frame, you can move it freely under the sewing foot. The pre-drawn buttons are ideal for this technique. Make sure your stitches aren't too short. A stitch length of 2–2.5mm (13 stitches per inch) will show the thread at its best. If you want to embroider areas and contours, the contours will be much clearer if you sew them at the end. It is also better to sew any special effects, such as lines in gold, after all the other colours.

tips: Metallic yarns are not as strong as other yarns, and are also far more sensitive.
If the yarn breaks frequently or starts to fray, you might need to check the needle.
You can also buy special needles for metallic yarns, which have a bigger eye than normal needles.
Sometimes it can help to loosen the upper tension a little.

projects.name: The backing

materials.dimensions: approx. 2cm (3/4in) longer than button, half width of button + 4cm (1 1/2in) seam allowance
approx. 2cm (3/4in) longer than button, half width of button + 4cm (1 1/2in) seam allowance
3mm (1/8in) smaller than button on all sides

tools.name: scissors
tools.purpose: to trim seam allowances and snip

steps.instruction: On each rectangle, iron one side edge 1cm (3/8 in) to the wrong side. Place the white coat button on the cut edge as illustrated, and draw the outline on the fold. Prepare both pieces like this, and sew along the drawn line.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a finger holding a white button against a yellow fabric edge, with a blue pen marking the fold line.

steps.instruction: Place the pieces together with the right sides facing and sew up the middle seam on the sides, leaving an opening in the middle that is a little smaller than the finished button. Do not pick up the fold on the version with the white coat button. Place the rectangles on the top of the button and mark the opening.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows two fabric pieces with pink and white patterns, sewn together with a visible seam and an opening. Image 3 shows a yellow fabric rectangle with a sewn edge, indicating a seam allowance.

steps.instruction: Iron the seam allowance apart. Place the back on the front of the button with the right sides together. If you hold the pieces against the light, you can check that the seam and opening are in the middle. Sew the two pieces together in the desired button shape. Trim the seam allowances back to 5mm (¼in).
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows two fabric circles, one pink and one yellow, placed right sides together, with a seam line visible.

steps.instruction: On the rounded section, snip into the seam allowance, leaving short gaps between, to just before the seam. Turn the button piece right side out. Push the seam to the outside with your fingers.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows a close-up of a curved seam allowance being snipped with scissors, with short gaps between the snips.

steps.instruction: Place the button on the interfacing, draw around, and cut out 3mm (1/8 in) smaller than the button on all sides.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a hand holding a button shape on a piece of interfacing, with a blue pen drawing around the button.

steps.instruction: Cut a hole in the middle of the interfacing to make it looser. Push the interfacing into the button. Stuff the button with a little wadding/batting if required. Push the uncovered button into the pre-sewn pocket and sew up the opening with fell stitches.
steps.visual_description: Image 7 shows a piece of interfacing with a hole cut in the center, placed on top of a fabric piece with a seam.

tips: A split backing makes it easy to turn the button right side out, stuff it and sew up the turning opening – a neat solution!
If you hold the pieces against the light, you can check that the seam and opening are in the middle.
Sew any beads on at the end. Sew one or two small stitches after sewing on three or four beads so that the beads will not come loose too easily.

projects.name: Felt Backings for Buttons

materials.item: shank button or split ring button

steps.instruction: Use felting wool to create sewing backgrounds with beautiful flowing colours. Place the felt fibres on the felt base, then start by gently rubbing the felting needle all over the fibres in the fabric, and then gradually build up the pressure. This will gradually produce a fuzz on the back of the fabric. For non-detachable buttons or buttons on smooth, loosely woven fabrics, be sure to wet felt the felt fibres on both sides of the fabric. Soak the fibres in hot, soapy water and rub together to felt them. Work very gently at first using small movements until the fibres have felted and can no longer slip. Now increase the pressure and use bigger movements.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a felting needle and brush on a grey fabric with purple and blue felt fibres.

steps.instruction: Sew over the felt surface. Small circles, polka dot patterns, zigzags and spirals are just a few examples of what you can do. If the felt fibres are pushed into the fabric with a felting needle, the sewn stitches need to be worked close together in order to prevent the fibres from being pulled out when doing up and undoing the buttons. Then work the back (see page 28).
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a felted background with embroidered stitches forming a circular pattern.

steps.instruction: Lace or printed fabrics also make good bases for sewing because they already include the pattern. If you are using lace, back with a different fabric and then set the two in the frame. Then sew over or complete the areas, contours etc. that are indicated by the lace.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows lace fabric with embroidered floral motifs, held in an embroidery hoop.

steps.instruction: To mark the button outlines on the back, sew a line at the desired distance from the motif plus a seam allowance of 1mm (1/32 in), ideally in a contrasting colour. Then work the back (see page 28), sewing the edge of the button close to the sewn marker line.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows an embroidery hoop with a piece of orange fabric, with a faint floral outline drawn on it.

tips: Fragile buttons will last longer if the button holes are big enough for the buttons to slide through without having to be forced.
projects.finished_product_description: Buttons made with felted backgrounds, lace, or printed fabrics, featuring embroidered designs and potentially beads.

diagram_descriptions: Top-left image shows three finished buttons: a round one with a spiral stitch, a rectangular one with a textured, layered felt design, and a smaller rectangular one with a similar textured design.

Top-right image shows two finished buttons: a round one with intricate floral embroidery in pinks and purples, and a larger round one with detailed floral embroidery in reds and yellows with gold thread accents.

projects.name: Embroidered Buttons

materials.notes: some relatively firm fabrics; a few layers of a transparent fabric and a firm base fabric is recommended

materials.item: shank button or split ring button

steps.instruction: Transfer the preliminary drawings onto the fabric or fleece (see page 30).
Set the fabric in an embroidery frame and embroider the top of the button (see page 26).
Place the iron-on fleece on the pattern with the fabric side up and draw circles for the appliqués. Put all the circles of the same colour that you want to cut out close together.
Iron the fleece onto the wrong sides of the various fabrics and cut the circles out precisely. Pull off the protective paper. Place the circles on the base fabric and iron on.
Sew the decorative lines first, then set the stitch to zigzag (still using the embroidery foot and with the feed dogs down) and appliqué the fabric circles.
Either sew a fabric backing (see page 28) or put the buttons on a button blank (see pages 43–44). Make the buttons big enough for an edge of the background fabric to be visible.
steps.notes: ensure background fabric edge is visible

projects.name: Felt Buttons

steps.instruction: Cover your working area with bubble wrap or a bamboo mat and prepare some hot, soapy water. You will need to add more hot water and soap as required. With their rough surfaces, bubble wrap or bamboo place mats make good felting bases that you can roll the felt balls over after felting the outer layer.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows wool, soap, and a cup of water, with a piece of bubble wrap in the background.

steps.instruction: Pull off a number of clumps of wool, each in the same size. Tie a knot at the end of one strand and wrap the wool around it to make a sphere.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows hands holding a clump of wool, preparing to form it into a ball.

steps.instruction: It's a good idea to make all the balls at the same time. The finished balls will be about one-third bigger than what you started with. Felt a sample ball to obtain the correct button size.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows several small, felted balls, some with a ruler indicating size.

steps.instruction: Pull a few fibres off the coloured felt and wrap around the ball. It only takes a few fibres to make eye-catching lines.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows hands wrapping thin fibres of coloured felt around a small wool ball.

tips: Bubble wrap or bamboo place mats make good felting bases.
Make all the balls at the same time.
Felt a sample ball to obtain the correct button size.
It only takes a few fibres to make eye-catching lines.
projects.finished_product_description: Felt buttons that feel fantastic and look great, decorated with embroidery and beads.

Some buttons have floral embroidery, while others have simple beaded lines. A glass dish filled with pink and orange beads is visible, along with spools of pink and light pink embroidery thread and a small pink ribbon rose embellishment.

projects.name: Embroidered Buttons

steps.instruction: Dip the sphere in the soapy water. When you first start, gently stroke the surface of the ball until the outer layer just starts to felt and has a certain degree of firmness. To achieve even results, it is essential that you start out by felting slowly using tiny movements and no pressure.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white ball with a green stripe, dipping it into soapy water.

steps.instruction: Continue felting.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white ball with a green stripe, rolling it between fingers.

steps.instruction: Once you have felted the outer layer, increase the pressure and use bigger circles. Keep dipping the ball in the hot water, and squeeze it occasionally to make sure that the water gets right to the centre of it. You can make a nugget as an alternative to a ball. Flatten the felt ball after felting it, and rub it in your hand until it has the desired firmness.
steps.visual_description: A small white ball with a green stripe next to a larger, more felted white ball. A ruler is shown below them, indicating approximately 6cm.

steps.instruction: When the ball is about half to one-third as big as at the beginning, halve it with a cutter so that the coloured lines are roughly in the middle over the hemisphere. Continue felting the hemispheres in your hand until the cut is rounded.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white ball with a green stripe, using a craft knife to cut it in half.

steps.instruction: Satin stitch: A basic stitch that creates terrific effects. Lots of tiny satin stitches worked evenly over an area are also called bourdon stitches. Pull the needle out in the desired spot and insert it again 1–3mm (1/32 –1/8 in) beside that spot and guide the needle straight to the next exit point. On fixed buttons, you might prefer to guide the needle to the underside of the button first, and then on to the next stitch.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white felted ball with a green stripe, a needle with green thread is shown inserting into the ball.

steps.instruction: Daisy stitch: Pull the needle out at the first insertion point and insert it again. Pull it out at the second insertion point and loop the thread under the needle. Draw the thread through, put the loop in the right position, and insert the needle at the second insertion point again. This time, though, on the other side of the loop so that it is secured in place with a tiny stitch. Pull the needle out again at the beginning of the next stitch.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white felted ball with a green stripe, a needle with green thread is shown creating a stitch.

steps.instruction: French knot: Pull the needle out at the desired point, then gently pull on the thread and wrap it around the needle one to three times, close to the exit point. Insert the needle close to or into the exit point. Pull the thread through the loops on the needle and through the fabric. Keep the thread taut so that the loops on the needle stay firmly in place and make a knot.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white felted ball with a green stripe, a needle with green thread is shown preparing to make a French knot.

steps.instruction: Continue making French knots.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small white felted ball with a green stripe, a needle with green thread is shown completing a French knot.

steps.instruction: To use when sewing on the button, attach a split ring to the back of the button after embroidering the felt buttons.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a finished embroidered button with green floral designs and blue beads on a white fuzzy background.

tips: You can make a nugget as an alternative to a ball. Flatten the felt ball after felting it, and rub it in your hand until it has the desired firmness.
On fixed buttons, you might prefer to guide the needle to the underside of the button first, and then on to the next stitch.

projects.name: Hand Embroidered Buttons

materials.color: yellow, orange, green, blue, red and magenta

steps.instruction: Set the fabric in the frame (small ring on top, large ring under the fabric), then place on the templates on page 42 and colour in the desired areas.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a white fabric pen, drawing on white fabric stretched in an embroidery hoop. The fabric has faint circular and square outlines.

steps.instruction: For finer outlines, start by drawing the contours with a thin fabric pen, then fill in the area with a thicker one. For adjoining areas, let the first colour dry before applying the second one. Leave enough space between the drawings for a circle of 45mm (1¾in) diameter for the round heads, and one of 40mm (1½in) diameter for the squares. Embroider the coloured areas in various stitches (satin stitch and French knots, see page 38).
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a hand holding a red fabric pen, drawing a flower outline on white fabric stretched in an embroidery hoop. The fabric has faint outlines of flowers and squares.

steps.instruction: Backstitch: This is sewn from right to left. Pull the needle out in the desired spot, then move it along 3mm (1/8 in) to the left and insert it, then pull it out again. Pull the thread through.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand holding a needle with purple thread, pulling it through white fabric. The needle is positioned to the left of where the thread exits the fabric.

steps.instruction: Move the needle 3mm (1/8 in) back to the right, and insert it in the last point again. Move to the left under the fabric, and pull it out 3mm (1/8 in) to the left of the last point of exit. Keep repeating this sequence.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a hand holding a needle with purple thread, inserting it into white fabric. The needle is positioned to the right of where the thread exits the fabric.

steps.instruction: Chain stitch: This is worked from the bottom to the top. Draw the needle out at the desired point and pull the thread up.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows a hand holding a needle with light blue thread, pulling it up through white fabric. A loop of thread is visible around the needle.

steps.instruction: Insert the needle in the same place again, then pull it out approximately 3mm (1/8 in) further up, winding a loop around the needle.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a hand holding a needle with light blue thread, inserting it into white fabric next to where the thread exited. A loop of thread is around the needle.

steps.instruction: Pull the thread through and make the first chain link. Repeat from *. Cover the buttons (see pages 43–44).
steps.visual_description: Image 7 shows a hand holding a needle with light blue thread, pulling it through white fabric to complete a chain stitch. A loop of thread is around the needle.

projects.name: Covering buttons

tools.name: pliers
tools.purpose: draw fabric over button and push over hooks

steps.instruction: The packaging for the button blanks should include information on the required fabric. For embroidered buttons (or if choosing a particular fabric cut-out), it is easier to work with a transparent template that you can cut out in accordance with the information on the packaging. If only cardboard is available, simply cut a hole in the middle of the template to position the circle correctly.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a transparent template with a circular design over a piece of red fabric, with a marker pen tip visible.

steps.instruction: Cut out the circle and place around the top of the button. Check the position of the motif.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a hand holding a red fabric circle with an embroidered spiral design, positioned over the top of a button blank.

steps.instruction: Using the pliers, draw the fabric over the button on four sides, and push over the hooks. Check the position of the motif again.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand using pliers to pull the red fabric over the edge of the button blank, with the hooks visible.

steps.instruction: Draw the fabric firmly over the edge so that it is lying smoothly and evenly on the button.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a hand using pliers to tuck the red fabric under the edge of the button blank, ensuring it lies smoothly.

steps.instruction: Push the underside of the button onto the back until it clicks into place.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows the back of a button with the fabric covering secured, and the underside being pressed into place.

steps.instruction: The button you can see here was sewn freehand (see page 26). All you need as the preliminary drawing are a few circles for division. Measure the button blank to establish the diameter of the circle that will be seen on the front of the finished button. The rest of the pattern is created directly under the sewing machine.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a finished embroidered button with a spiral and geometric pattern on a red fabric background.

tips: If only cardboard is available, simply cut a hole in the middle of the template to position the circle correctly.
projects.finished_product_description: An embroidered button cover.

templates.name: Button Templates
templates.shape_description: A collection of circular templates with various black and white patterns. Some templates have a red outer circle indicating the visible area on the finished button. The patterns include a gear-like shape, concentric circles, a flower with 6 petals, a flower with 10 petals, a square within a square, and a 3x3 grid of squares.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the red lines on the templates indicate the area that will be visible on the finished button.

projects.name: Covering Old Buttons

steps.instruction: Draw a circle on the fabric with a diameter about twice that of the button. Cut out the circle.
dimensions_mentioned: twice the diameter of the button
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand drawing a circle on blue polka dot fabric with a marker pen, with a button and a piece of fabric next to it.

steps.instruction: Cut out another circle about 3–5mm (1/8 –¼in) bigger than the button for the back of the button. If required, cut a button-sized circle out of fleece so that the surface of the button is smooth.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a white button with four holes, a blue polka dot fabric circle, and a small white fleece circle.

steps.instruction: Fold over the edges of the circle for the back and iron them to the wrong side to make a hexagon. The hexagon should be a little smaller than the button.
dimensions_mentioned: a little smaller than the button
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a blue polka dot fabric folded into a hexagon shape, with the edges tucked in.

steps.instruction: Tack the circle for the front using a needle and double thread.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a blue polka dot fabric circle with a running stitch around the edge, with thread visible.

steps.instruction: Put the button (with the volume fleece, if desired) into the circle and pull the ends of the thread together so that the fabric encloses the button. Knot the ends of the threads and secure.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows the blue polka dot fabric gathered around a button, with the thread pulled taut.

steps.instruction: Place the button back on the front and sew on using blind stitches. Push the needle out on the edge of the back, and insert it in the fabric just above that point. Then move the needle to the left under the fabric, and pull it out on the edge. Keep repeating this sequence.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a close-up of fingers using a needle and thread to sew the back of the button onto the fabric front.

steps.instruction: This is what the back of the finished button will look like. The button is simply sewn on through the fabric. Alternatively, you could crochet a back. Crochet rounds one to four (see page 62), and push a hook eye (see page 23) into the opening before tightening the loop.
steps.visual_description: Image 7 shows the finished covered button from the back, with the fabric neatly gathered and secured.

tips: Although this technique requires a little more effort, it can give even the shabbiest button a new lease on life.
Alternatively, you could crochet a back. Crochet rounds one to four (see page 62), and push a hook eye (see page 23) into the opening before tightening the loop.

projects.name: Cartoon buttons

materials.notes: linen batiste is best for tracing patterns

steps.instruction: Place the fabric on the pattern (see patterns on page 49), and use a light box to project your image (a light under an empty picture frame glass will also do the trick). Draw over the lines with the marker pen.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a marker pen over a piece of fabric with a projected outline of a bear's face.

steps.instruction: Set up your sewing machine for freehand embroidery. Fit the embroidery or quilting foot and lower or cover the feed dogs. Refer to the manufacturer's instructions for further information. Use black sewing thread.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a close-up of the fabric with the bear's face outline drawn on it, with red lines indicating the embroidery path.

steps.instruction: Here is one possible sewing sequence: sew two to three stitches in one place before stopping and at the beginning and end of the short lines (the double lines are easy to see, and should be positioned evenly, i.e. sew both connecting lines to the ears, or the two ears, double). Always sew double on the outer frame. For the flower (see photo on right), first embroider the area in pink and then follow the contours in black.
steps.notes: Always sew double on the outer frame. For the flower, embroider the area in pink first, then the contours in black.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a close-up of an embroidered button with a bear's face, with red lines indicating the embroidery path. There are also small diagrams of a bird and a rabbit.

tips: A trendy illustrated button will look good on a denim jacket or bag.
If you don’t like embroidering, you can draw the patterns yourself with a fabric pen.

projects.name: Embroidered Buttons

steps.instruction: Cut 4cm (1½in) pieces of aluminium wire.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a piece of gold-colored wire and bending it with pliers.

steps.instruction: First fold the wire in half to form a shank in the middle. Bend the ends outward to the angle as shown in the picture. The shank should be about 5mm (¼in) high.
steps.visual_description: A piece of gold-colored wire folded in half with ends bent outwards, forming a shank.

steps.instruction: Use the roller cutter to cut out two squares of interfacing measuring 3.25 x 3.25cm (1 3/8 x 1 3/8 in) for each button. Draw the diagonals on one square to mark the middle. Use the punch pliers to make a 3–4mm (1/8 –¼ in) hole in the middle. The shank needs to fit through this hole. Iron the square without the hole onto the wrong side of the embroidery. The square should just cover the embroidered frame. Trim the top and bottom of the fabric 1.5cm (½in) from the interfacing, and the sides 2.5cm (1in) from the interfacing.
steps.visual_description: Two squares of light-colored interfacing are shown. One has a small hole in the center. Another square is placed on top of a piece of white fabric.

steps.instruction: Place the shank on the square so that it is parallel to the top edge of the fabric. Put the square with the hole over the shank and iron onto the first square. Iron the damp cloth around the shank a few times.
steps.visual_description: A piece of white fabric with an interfacing square attached. A metal shank is placed on top, and another interfacing square with a hole is placed over it. A needle is shown piercing the fabric near the shank.

steps.instruction: Iron the top and bottom edge of the fabric back around the edge of the interfacing, making the sides a little wider so that the strip is narrower to the outside (see image). Then iron the side edges back.
steps.visual_description: The edges of the white fabric are folded back over the interfacing square, creating a neat edge around the shank.

steps.instruction: Open out the side edges and tighten the cut edges that meet at the centre with satin stitch, and secure (inserting the needle in the right side of the fabric, guide the needle to the left under the fabric and pull it through).
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the fabric edges being sewn together with satin stitch, with a needle and thread visible.

steps.instruction: Fold the raw edges of the sides to the wrong side so that the cut edges meet at the shank. Secure the sides with fell stitches. Secure the thread on the inside, then push the needle through the edge that is to be attached. Insert the needle in the fabric close to the exit point, and guide the needle to the left through the fabric. Pull the needle out about 2mm (1/16 in) further along on the edge, and insert it again just above the edge and guide the needle to the left. Any stitches that show will be tiny.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the fabric edges being sewn with small stitches, with a needle and thread in action.

steps.instruction: This is what the back of the finished button will look like.
steps.visual_description: The back of a finished embroidered button, showing the fabric neatly folded and secured around the metal shank.

projects.finished_product_description: A fabric button with an embroidered design on the front and a metal shank on the back.

templates.name: Animal Templates
templates.shape_description: Outline drawings of various animals within square frames. Animals include a frog with a crown, a rabbit's head, a moose's head, a cat's head, a person's head with glasses, a giraffe's head, a flower, a bunny's head, a bear's head, and a bird.

Photo showing two squares of interfacing, one with a hole, and a square of interfacing on fabric.
Photo showing a shank placed on fabric with interfacing, and another piece of interfacing with a hole placed over it, ready for ironing.
Photo showing the fabric edges folded back around the interfacing.

projects.name: Roll-ups

materials.notes: if required (to join several ribbons together)

steps.instruction: Cut a strip of fabric to double the height of the book screw plus 1–2mm (1/32 –1/16 in). Iron the two cut edges over to the middle of the strip with the wrong sides facing so that the fabric is doubled all over. Line narrow strips up close together and iron fleece onto the wrong side to join them together. Trim the strips to 9.5cm (3¾in).
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows several strips of patterned fabric, some with yellow tape on the ends, laid out side-by-side.

steps.instruction: Stick the adhesive tape onto the back of the strip, taking care to cover the cut sides of the fabric.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a strip of fabric with yellow double-sided tape applied to it. A hand is holding scissors, about to trim the tape.

steps.instruction: Screw the book screw together. Pull the backing off the adhesive tape and wrap the strip firmly around the screw.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand wrapping a fabric strip around a book screw. The backing of the adhesive tape is being pulled off.

steps.instruction: Trim off any excess fabric and fold the end 0.5cm (¼in) over to the wrong side. Place a small piece of adhesive tape onto the fold and press down firmly. Secure the strip with fell stitches. Pull the needle through on the edge, then insert it just above the edge and guide the needle through the fabric and slightly to the left. Insert it in the edge again and work the next stitch.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a close-up of a hand sewing a fabric-wrapped book screw. The needle is being pulled through the fabric.

steps.instruction: Sew a split ring on at the middle of the seam. First secure the thread with two or three stitches, then push through the ring and the fabric a few times.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows a hand sewing a split ring onto the fabric-wrapped book screw. The needle and thread are visible.

steps.instruction: Wind the thread around the stitching at the bottom of the ring a few times and secure the thread with a few stitches. Sew up the second half of the seam.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a close-up of the finished fabric-wrapped book screw with a split ring attached. The stitching is visible.

projects.finished_product_description: Book screws wrapped in fabric or ribbon, resembling spools of thread.

A wooden shelf unit filled with spools of ribbon and fabric scraps. Some spools are wrapped in patterned fabric, others are actual ribbon spools. One shelf has a decorative illustration of jars and cakes.

projects.name: Monkey's Fist Knot

steps.instruction: Leave about 10cm (4in) of one end of the satin cord hanging and hold it with the thumb and ring finger of your left hand. Slightly spread your index and middle fingers, and wrap the cord around them five times. Move the free end of the cord behind the wraps to the left and then between your index and middle fingers at the front.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding the end of a cord, with the cord wrapped around the index and middle fingers five times. The free end is shown behind the wraps.

steps.instruction: Wind the cord five times around the vertical wraps from left to right. The resulting space should be big enough for the bead.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding the wrapped cord, with another wrap being added horizontally five times. The space created is shown to be large enough for a bead.

steps.instruction: Push the bead into the space, holding the wraps tight with your thumb.
steps.visual_description: A hand pushing a bead into the center of the wrapped cord, with the thumb holding the wraps in place.

steps.instruction: Carefully move the wraps a little to the front with your index and middle fingers, making the openings bigger. Thread the free end of the cord through the opening over the ball and the horizontal wraps, working from front to back.
steps.visual_description: A hand adjusting the wraps to enlarge the opening. The free end of the cord is being threaded through the opening over the bead and horizontal wraps.

steps.instruction: Continue from back to front under the ball, and wrap five times around the horizontal wraps.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding the knot, showing the cord being wrapped five times around the horizontal wraps, starting from under the ball.

steps.instruction: Pull all the wraps tight. Start with the first wraps that are still very loose, and wind each one individually around the ball from the beginning of the cord to the end of each wrap.
steps.visual_description: A hand pulling the wraps tight, individually adjusting each wrap around the ball.

steps.instruction: This is what the finished ball will look like – called a "monkey's fist". If the cord and/or ball have different diameters, this will change the number of wraps required. The knot makes a very pretty fastening.
steps.visual_description: A finished monkey's fist knot, which is a tightly wrapped ball of cord with two ends extending from it.

tips: If the cord and/or ball have different diameters, this will change the number of wraps required.
projects.finished_product_description: A "monkey's fist" knot, which is a decorative and functional fastening made from cord and a bead. It is shown attached to a piece of fabric with embroidered flowers.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up image of a piece of brown fabric with green embroidered vines and flowers. Several green monkey's fist knots are attached to the fabric as fasteners.

projects.name: Macramé Fastening

steps.instruction: Start by crocheting three chain stitches. Insert the hook into the second chain (red arrow), then into the first chain (green arrow). Draw yarn through the first two loops on the hook. Draw yarn through the remaining two loops on the hook.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of fingers holding a crochet hook and yarn, with three chain stitches. Red and green arrows indicate insertion points for the hook.

steps.instruction: Insert hook in the three loops at the bottom (see image).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of fingers holding a crochet hook and yarn, showing three loops on the hook.

steps.instruction: Turn the work around so that the loops are at the top of the hook. Draw yarn through the first two loops on the hook. Draw yarn through the remaining two loops on the hook.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of fingers holding a crochet hook and yarn, with loops positioned at the top of the hook.

steps.instruction: Insert hook through the two loops on the right edge of the work (see arrows). Turn the work around again and work the loops on the hook as described above. Continue working step 4.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of fingers holding a crochet hook and yarn, showing two loops on the hook with red and green arrows indicating insertion points.

tips: Sew the outer loops together at the colour transitions in the drawing. The numbers indicate which loop is to be sewn on.
First sew the cord together at the green/red transitions, then sew on the cord end at the middle and finally sew on the loop or the end with the ball.
projects.finished_product_description: Macramé cords are usually crocheted together to make little doilies. However, they are also delightful sewn together as fastenings.

diagram_descriptions: Crochet diagram showing a circular pattern with numbered sections (1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 13, 18, 37) and colored lines (green, red, blue, orange) indicating stitches and connections. Some sections are labeled with numbers like '18' and '37'. A section is labeled '13 to the ball'.
Image 1: Close-up of hands holding a crochet hook and light blue yarn, forming three chain stitches. Red and green arrows point to specific loops.
Image 2: Close-up of hands holding a crochet hook and light blue yarn, showing three loops on the hook. Green and red arrows point to loops.
Image 3: Close-up of hands holding a crochet hook and light blue yarn, with loops positioned at the top of the hook.
Image 4: Close-up of hands holding a crochet hook and light blue yarn, showing two loops on the hook. Red and green arrows point to insertion points.

projects.name: Sewing Cords

tools.name: sewing machine
tools.purpose: sewing cords and attaching to fabric

steps.instruction: Cut equal lengths of various yarns. Lower or cover the feed dogs (refer to the instructions for your machine) and insert an embroidery or quilting foot. Set to the widest zigzag stitch. Place the yarns under the sewing foot, twisting them slightly to make a round cord. Make sure that the needle always goes in to the left and right sides of the yarns when sewing.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a sewing machine needle and foot sewing together multiple strands of yarn, creating a twisted cord.

steps.instruction: The tension of the sewing thread determines what the cord will look like. In this picture, the cords have both been made of the same yarns, however, the top one was oversewn in turquoise and metallic turquoise, and the bottom one in pink.
steps.visual_description: Two examples of sewn cords. The top cord is a mix of turquoise and metallic turquoise yarns. The bottom cord is pink yarn. Both are shown with a slight twist.

steps.instruction: You can add tiny patterns to a cord that has already been sewn. Sew over a small section in a tight zigzag, then change to straight stitch and sew 1–2cm (3/8 –¾in) along the middle of the cord. Then sew a small section in zigzag again. To create a different effect, change the stitch length, i.e. sew very tight stitches and then change to ones with larger gaps between them. This creates different colour shades in the cord. The more you sew over the cord, the denser and stronger it will be.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a blue yarn cord with yellow stitching in a zigzag pattern along its length.

steps.instruction: Instead of making loose cords, you can also sew slightly twisted yarns straight onto fabric. It‘s best to set the fabric in an embroidery frame for this, then place the bundled yarns on it and sew a few stitches at the beginning to secure. Then sew on the yarns in your choice of pattern with freehand zigzag stitches. Use the fabric to cover button blanks (see pages 43–44). You can also sew on some beads if you like.
steps.visual_description: A piece of light-colored fabric stretched in a wooden embroidery hoop. Several strands of pink yarn are arranged in a star-like pattern and secured with stitches at the center.

tips: Find the matching button to go with any knitted item. All you need to do is combine your knitting yarn with a few yarn remnants and...hey presto! – you have the perfect button.
The tension of the sewing thread determines what the cord will look like.
To create a different effect, change the stitch length, i.e. sew very tight stitches and then change to ones with larger gaps between them. This creates different colour shades in the cord.
The more you sew over the cord, the denser and stronger it will be.
It‘s best to set the fabric in an embroidery frame for this.
You can also sew on some beads if you like.
projects.finished_product_description: Buttons and cords made from twisted and sewn yarns, some with added beads and decorative stitching.

diagram_descriptions: A collection of finished sewing cord projects, including several buttons covered with decorative yarn stitching and beads, and some loose cords made from colorful yarns with metallic threads.

projects.name: Cord Buttons (Monkey's Fist Knot)

materials.item: plastic bead or wooden ball (Version A)

tools.name: crochet hook
tools.purpose: pulling threads through to the back

steps.instruction: Make a monkey's fist knot (see page 52), but don't pull the wraps too tight. Carefully push the wraps apart at an intersection and push the ball out. Take care to move the wraps as little as possible.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows hands holding a purple cord monkey's fist knot with a silver bead being pushed into its center.

steps.instruction: Flatten the knot, leaving the hole at the bottom.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a flattened purple cord monkey's fist knot with a hole at the bottom.

steps.instruction: If necessary, pull the threads through to the back with a crochet hook.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a crochet hook pulling a purple cord thread through the back of the knot.

steps.instruction: Sew through the knot several times to make it stronger. Sew the split ring to the back.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a sewing needle stitching through a purple cord knot, with a gold-colored split ring attached to the back.

steps.instruction: Make a monkey's fist knot (see page 52) without a ball. Make sure that the vertical and horizontal wraps in the final step are all evenly tied. To tighten the knot, just pull the first wraps that are standing out. Follow the cord from the protruding beginning to the last overhanging wrap before the horizontal wraps start. Start at this point and tighten the wraps towards the beginning.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows hands tying a blue cord monkey's fist knot, without a central bead.

steps.instruction: This is what the finished knot will look like. Sew through the knot several times to make it stronger. Sew the split ring onto the back and, if you like, add a decorative bead onto the front.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows a finished blue cord monkey's fist knot, tightly tied. Image B shows a blue/green cord button with a blue decorative bead on the front.

tips: Make sure that the vertical and horizontal wraps in the final step are all evenly tied.
projects.finished_product_description: Knotted cord buttons, either round with a central bead (Version A) or a flattened, decorative knot (Version B).

projects.name: Cord Button (Spirals on Grid)

steps.instruction: Push the start of the cord through the front and the middle opening in the button grid, and secure on the back with a few stitches.
steps.visual_description: Image shows hands pushing a purple cord through the center of a clear plastic grid button.

steps.instruction: Wrap the cord around the middle of the front in three spirals, connecting the rounds to each other and to the button.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a purple cord wrapped in three spirals on the clear plastic grid button, with a needle securing a loop.

steps.instruction: Then lay the loops and again sew to the button and surrounding loops.
Sew a bead into the middle of each loop. After the final loop, feed the end of the cord to the back through a button opening and secure.

projects.finished_product_description: A round button with cord wrapped in spirals on a plastic grid, with small beads sewn into the loops, featuring a scalloped edge.

projects.name: Cord Button (Embroidered Fleece)

steps.instruction: Sew the cords (see page 56). Set the embroidery fleece in an embroidery frame.
Carefully slit the protective paper in the middle with the cutter and tear, leaving a sticky area that is a little bigger than you want the button to be.
Stick the cord to the fleece in your chosen pattern, hiding the beginning and end of the cord under the arranged cord.
steps.visual_description: Image shows examples of cord patterns on embroidery fleece: a rectangular shape with parallel lines and a circular spiral pattern.

steps.instruction: Place the button shape down but without pushing it into place. Cut the cord to the required length.
Lift the cord off the fleece, push the end of the cord under it and press down on the arranged cord.
Machine sew a few stitches over the cord.
Cut out a piece of interfacing that is about 1mm (¹⁄₃₂in) smaller all round than the button.
Punch a little hole in the middle to make it easier to sew the beads and button on later.
Iron the interfacing onto the back. Continue sewing over the front.
Tear off the embroidery fleece and sew the split ring onto the back.
Push the needle through the whole button and secure the front.
Sew the bead and mother-of-pearl disc to the top of the button.

tips: Punch a little hole in the middle to make it easier to sew the beads and button on later.
projects.finished_product_description: A button made from cord arranged in a pattern on embroidered fleece, with an interfacing backing, and optional mother-of-pearl disc and rocailles on top.
