projects.name: Flower Power Buttons

steps.instruction: Cut two or three circles the size of your desired button and place them on top of each other with the grain on each circle facing a different way (see arrows).
steps.visual_description: Three denim circles layered on top of each other, with arrows indicating different grain directions.

steps.instruction: Draw your chosen motif into the middle of one of the circles. If you prefer, you can also transfer the motif to water-soluble fleece (see page 30) and place that on the circles. Place the circles neatly on a piece of fabric that is big enough to cover the button. Sew the motif onto the middle of the circle.
steps.visual_description: A denim circle with a peace sign motif drawn in the center. Another image shows a hand holding a denim circle with a peace sign, with frayed edges starting to form.

steps.instruction: Cover the button (see pages 43–44) and fray the edges of the circles. This is best done by separating the threads with a needle or using pliers to catch the ends of the threads and pulling them out. If you are using a thinner fabric, you might find it easier to moisten it and rub a hard brush over the edge to fray it.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a hand using fingers to fray the edges of a denim circle, revealing threads.

tips: Denim can be quite tough and it will require a bit of patience to fray the edges properly, but it'll take no time at all to sew on the peace sign and smileys.
projects.finished_product_description: Decorative buttons made from frayed denim circles with embroidered motifs like peace signs, smiley faces, yin-yang symbols, and flowers.

diagram_descriptions: Image 1: Three denim circles layered, with arrows indicating different grain directions.
Image 2: A denim circle with a peace sign motif embroidered in the center.
Image 3: A hand fraying the edges of a denim circle, showing individual threads being pulled.
Various finished buttons with different embroidered motifs (smiley face, peace sign, yin-yang, flower, skull and crossbones, radiation symbol, star) displayed on a white shirt.
A blue and white toy van.
Decorative purple flowers with yellow centers, connected by a purple string.

projects.name: Crocheted buttons

steps.instruction: The stitches in the first round will be crocheted in a loop: wrap a loop around the middle finger of your left hand, and hold the end of it with the ring finger of the same hand.
steps.visual_description: Close-up photo of hands wrapping purple yarn around the middle finger to form a loop, with the end held by the ring finger.

steps.instruction: Push the hook under the loop and pull one loop through, still holding on to the end of the yarn.
steps.visual_description: Close-up photo of a crochet hook inserted under the purple yarn loop on the finger, pulling a new loop through.

steps.instruction: Work one chain, i.e. draw another loop through the loop on the hook.
steps.visual_description: Close-up photo showing the crochet hook with one loop, and the purple yarn being drawn through it to form a chain stitch.

steps.instruction: Next, crochet six single crochet (UK double) of the first round, insert the hook under the loop and draw yarn through so you have two loops on the hook. Then draw a loop through the two loops on the hook. End the first round with one slip stitch in the first single crochet (UK double crochet).
steps.technique: single crochet (UK double crochet), slip stitch
steps.visual_description: Close-up photo showing the initial chain stitches formed in a purple yarn loop, with the hook inserted into one of the stitches.

steps.instruction: When changing colours after the first round, work the slip stitches in the new colour. Work one chain stitch to change to second row. Work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into each stitch in the previous round, inserting the hook in the back loop only = twelve stitches. End the round with one slip stitch into the first single crochet (UK double crochet) (not into the chain stitch). Tighten the loop after the second round. Start each following round with one chain stitch.
steps.technique: color change, chain stitch, single crochet (UK double crochet), slip stitch, back loop only

steps.instruction: In the third round, work one single crochet (UK double crochet), then two single crochet (UK double crochet) into one stitch in the previous round = eighteen stitches.
In the fourth round, work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into stitch = twenty-four stitches.
In the fifth round, work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into every fourth stitch = thirty stitches.
In the sixth round, increase in every fifth stitch, and in the seventh round in every sixth stitch = forty-two stitches.

Start the next round on the back of the button. Secure yarn and place the shank button on the back of the work. Working in spirals (no chain between rounds), decrease two single crochet (UK double crochet) together (see page 11).
steps.technique: working in spirals, decrease two single crochet together

tips: Try sewing these onto cards to make the perfect home-made gift.
projects.finished_product_description: Crocheted buttons in various colors and patterns, some displayed on decorative cards.

diagram_descriptions: Numbered photo 1: Close-up of hands wrapping purple yarn around the middle finger of the left hand, holding the end with the ring finger to form a loop.
Numbered photo 2: Close-up of a crochet hook inserted under the purple yarn loop on the finger, pulling a new loop through.
Numbered photo 3: Close-up of a crochet hook with one loop, drawing another loop of purple yarn through it to form a chain stitch.
Numbered photo 4: Close-up of the initial chain stitches formed in a purple yarn loop, with the crochet hook inserted into one of the stitches, ready for the first single crochet.

Background collage featuring various vintage buttons, button boxes (e.g., 'Perletta' with 'PERLMUTTERKNOPF-IMITATION AUS ZELLULOID ca. 1,0mm stark, UNZERBRECHLICH IM GEBRAUCH' and 'Bodo' with '10 STCK. Junggesellen-Knöpfe VORZÜGLICHE QUALITÄT'), and several examples of finished crocheted buttons. The crocheted buttons include designs like pink and white concentric circles, solid pink with white dots, multi-colored concentric circles (yellow, blue, pink, green), and a gold crocheted flower with beaded center. Some crocheted buttons are displayed on decorative cards, one with the German text 'EIN KNOPF FÜR DICH' (A button for you) and another with a decorative pink border.

64   CROCHETED BUTTONS
CROCHETED BUTTONS   65
Materials
• very fine crochet yarn in white and magenta 
• crochet hook size 10–8 (1.25–1.5mm)
• shank buttons, approximately 27mm (1 1/16 in) diameter 
and 16mm (5/8 in) diameter 
• sharp embroidery needle 
How it‘s done
Button A: Crochet the first to seventh rounds (see page 62). Start 
with white and alternate the colour at the end of each round. Work 
the slip stitch in the new colour at the end of the round. Work the 
back in white (see page 62)

projects.name: Dog, Cat, Mouse Buttons

tools.name: sewing needle
tools.purpose: to pull out whiskers and secure thread

steps.instruction: The animal faces are crocheted on to plastic grid buttons, which are special transparent plastic buttons for sewing and crocheting. Crochet around the button to join the button top and bottom together. Join the yarn on an outside opening on the button. Observe the position of the shank in the crochet pattern to make sure that the hook eyes is more or less horizontal on the finished head; the shank should be facing down. Then work single crochet (UK double) into the opening as per the pattern and crochet on the ears.
steps.technique: crocheting around a plastic grid button
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a clear plastic grid button with crochet hook and gold yarn, starting to crochet around the edge. Number 1 is visible.

steps.instruction: The ears are crocheted on to the head and worked double to make sure they are firm and do not curl up. For the cat, for example, work six chain stitches for the front of the ear, then turn and work single crochet (UK double), half double (UK half treble) etc. into the chain stitch.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and green yarn, working on a crochet ear shape attached to a plastic button. Number 2 is visible.

steps.instruction: Fold over the back of the ear so that it is below the front part. For the mouse, you can work the loose links of four chains stitches onto the backs of the ears to match. The backs of the dog's ears are not folded over, but instead placed under the front parts of the ears. Like the fronts of the ears, the right sides of the backs point upwards.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and green yarn, showing the process of folding a crochet ear. Number 3 is visible.

steps.instruction: Insert the hook into the front of the ear from above, take up the back loop (or chain) of the front and back parts of the ear, and work one slip stitch to join them (shown in grey).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a crochet hook and green yarn, demonstrating joining the front and back of a crochet ear with a slip stitch. Number 4 is visible.

steps.instruction: When the top of the button is finished (see page 68), secure the ends of the black thread used for the nose, and sew on the mouth in backstitch (see page 40). The tip of the dog's and mouse's nose points up, whereas the cat's points down. To make the whiskers, knot together three pieces of black thread about 20cm (7¾in) long in the middle with a double knot. Push the knot into the nose and pull the individual whiskers out using a sewing needle or crochet hook. Use black sewing thread and a sewing needle to secure the whisker knot on the inside.

Then sew on the beads for the eyes. Draw the needle out in the desired spot, thread the white and then the black bead; feed the thread back through the white bead, and push into the crochet. Repeat this process once more. Secure the thread on the inside, and sew on the second eye in the same way. Make sure the thread is well secured.

tips: These animal buttons are adorable with cute faces and loyal, loving eyes. Crochet them in any colour!

projects.name: Crocheted Buttons

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in orange, white (for the mouse), light green (for the cat) and light blue (for the dog)
materials.color: orange, white, light green, light blue

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in black

steps.instruction: Crochet around the plastic grid buttons, and crochet on the ears (see page 67 and crochet pattern below).
Work the faces as shown in the pattern, then start with a loop of black thread (see page 62).
At the end of round one, change to the face colour, and start by working the slip stitch in the new colour.
Draw the loop up at the end of the last round (do not cut) and complete the face (see page 67).
Place the face on the bottom of the button and crochet both together around the edge in slip stitches, catching one outside stitch loop on the top and the bottom in your work.
On the ears, crochet the top to the loops around the grid head or else to the doubles (UK trebles).
A few stitches before the end of the round, stuff the head with wadding/batting and press into shape.

projects.finished_product_description: Crocheted buttons shaped like animal faces (mouse, cat, dog) attached to plastic grid buttons.

projects.name: Twiggy buttons

materials.notes: if using green wood, risk of splitting or rot

materials.item: small screw hooks or rivet pins

tools.name: drill
tools.notes: bit size slightly smaller than hook thread or rivet pin

steps.instruction: Pull the bark off the sticks. Saw the sticks to the size you want the buttons to be. Smooth the surfaces with the coarse sandpaper, then with the smoother sandpaper. Pre-drill a hole for the hook in the middle, then screw in the hook or drill a small hole through the piece of wood and push in the rivet pin and bend on the bottom to make a shank. Trim any overlapping material.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a drill bit making a hole. Image 2 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a screw hook being inserted.

steps.instruction: Push the skewer or cocktail stick through the hook so that you can hold the button by it. Prime the button with white acrylic paint and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a skewer inserted through the hook, and the wood is being painted white.

steps.instruction: Draw on dots, lines or patterns with the paint markers. Before adding any overlapping layers, allow the bottom one to dry well first.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand holding a piece of wood and drawing purple dots on it with a paint marker.

steps.instruction: Once the paint is dry, draw the contours and tiny dots with the fineliner. Leave the button to dry and then varnish.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a hand holding a piece of wood and drawing patterns with a black fineliner.

tips: Use screw punch for clean holes

projects.name: Driftwood buttons

materials.dimensions: 0.4mm (US 26 guage) diameter or a little thicker than the rivet pin

steps.instruction: Drill a little hole through the wood a little off-centre (at the spot where you want to start winding) and thread the end of the wire through from the top to the bottom.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of driftwood, with a thin wire being threaded through a small drilled hole.

steps.instruction: Wind it tightly around the piece of wood, perhaps including a bead in the middle of the winding on the top, and incorporating the split ring on the back. Push the bead and ring over the end of the wire, keeping the wire as straight as possible. You must not allow any bends or twists in the wire. In order to include the ring the second and third times, carefully pull the wire through the ring without letting it bend.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand winding gold wire around a piece of driftwood. A bead is shown on top of the wood, and a split ring is on the back.

steps.instruction: Wind it tightly around the piece of wood, perhaps including a bead in the middle of the winding on the top, and incorporating the split ring on the back. Push the bead and ring over the end of the wire, keeping the wire as straight as possible. You must not allow any bends or twists in the wire. In order to include the ring the second and third times, carefully pull the wire through the ring without letting it bend.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand winding gold wire around a piece of driftwood. A bead is shown on top of the wood, and a split ring is on the back.

steps.instruction: Once you have wound enough wire around the wood, wrap it around the starting point of the ring a few times.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand wrapping gold wire around the base of a split ring attached to a piece of driftwood.

steps.instruction: Twist the beginning and end of the wire together.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of hands twisting the ends of gold wire together on a piece of driftwood.

steps.instruction: Trim the ends of the wire and push them under the windings or ring.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand trimming gold wire ends on a piece of driftwood, with the ends being tucked under the windings.

steps.instruction: Rivet pin version: drill a hole in the middle of the piece of wood. Push a piece of shell or bead cap onto the pin, then push the rivet pin through the wood and bend the bottom to make a shank. Trim any overlapping material.
steps.visual_description: A piece of driftwood with a rivet pin inserted through a hole, with a shell or bead cap on top and the bottom bent to form a shank.

projects.finished_product_description: Charming driftwood buttons with a beach holiday vibe, created using gold wire or rivet pins and decorative elements like beads and shells.

projects.name: Clay Buttons

steps.instruction: Cut off a sufficient quantity of equally sized pieces of modelling clay. Kneading makes the clay soft and pliable. Many of these buttons are made by rolling a ball and then flattening it to make a circle or shaping into an oval. Be sure to use baking parchment as it's easy to pull the modelling clay off of after baking.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows three pieces of white modelling clay, one rectangular and two cut into smaller pieces. Image 2 shows a finger pressing a split ring into a flattened piece of white modelling clay with a tool.

steps.instruction: If you want to attach a shank on the back of the button, push the ring into the clay in the middle of the back. Make a little tie, push it through the ring and smooth it with a knife.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a finger pressing a split ring into a flattened piece of white modelling clay with a tool.

steps.instruction: To make the bird's head, start by flattening a ball of clay. For the beak, shape a piece about 2mm (1/16 in) thick with your hand and cut out one triangle.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a piece of orange clay being cut into a triangle with a knife. A red piece of clay is also visible.

steps.instruction: To make the eyes, roll a little line of clay, flatten it slightly and cut two slices out of the middle. Cut the bottom edge off in a straight line. Place the beak and eyes on the head and press down. To make the pupils, roll a thin line of clay and cut off two tiny pieces, then shape into balls and position on the eyes.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows two white oval shapes and two white rectangular shapes. Image 5 shows a red clay shape with a yellow beak and two white eyes with black pupils. A small black line is also visible.

steps.instruction: Two little rolled up pieces of aluminium foil will keep the shank buttons in place when baking them. Shank buttons with a flat top can also be put face down on the baking parchment for baking.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows three finished clay buttons shaped like birds with beaks and eyes, placed on crumpled aluminum foil.

projects.name: Modelling Clay Buttons

materials.details: white-transparent, yellow, orange, red, metallic blue, metallic white, pink, black

tools.name: wooden planks
tools.purpose: to ensure equal thickness of clay

tools.name: pin or needle
tools.purpose: to lift off beads or attach shank

tools.name: skewers
tools.purpose: to create graphic patterns or nostril holes

tools.name: smooth sandpaper
tools.purpose: to expose original colour on raised areas

steps.instruction: To make pieces of equal thickness, place the modelling clay between two wooden planks and roll out with the rolling pin. The clay will then be as thick as the planks.
steps.visual_description: A hand rolling a piece of red modelling clay between two wooden planks with a rolling pin.

steps.instruction: You can use almost any kind of stamp to make a relief-type surface. Either stamp a rolled out surface and then cut out the button, or shape a ball into the desired button and then stamp it.
steps.visual_description: A hand pressing a heart-shaped stamp into a piece of red modelling clay.

steps.instruction: Tiny beads and other buttons can also be used to make a pattern on the surface. Beads are easy to lift off again with a pin or needle as shown. If using shank buttons, attach the shank first and place the button on the two planks (which you have wrapped in aluminium foil) with the shank between the planks. Then decorate the button.
steps.visual_description: A hand using a needle to press small flower-shaped embellishments into a flat piece of grey modelling clay.

steps.instruction: Use the lid of a felt pen, skewers or a knife to create graphic patterns. Work all the way to the edge of the button by pressing in half motifs.
steps.visual_description: A hand pressing a small circular stamp with a geometric pattern into a grey modelling clay surface.

steps.instruction: After baking (refer to the manufacturer’s instructions), coat the buttons in clear varnish and leave to dry. Then paint the surface in a contrasting colour (acrylic paint) and wipe off with a paper towel so that the paint only remains in the indentations. Apply another layer of clear varnish to the buttons. It is not possible to wipe all of the paint off unvarnished buttons: the whole button is painted, and the colour is much stronger in the indentations. If you like, you can use smooth sandpaper on the raised areas to expose the original colour of the button.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a heart-shaped button and applying white paint to its surface with a brush, then wiping it with a cloth.

steps.instruction: For the striped buttons, roll very thin laces out on the baking parchment with flat hands. Place the laces on the rolled-out surface and push down with the rolling pin (running it over the two wooden battens).
steps.visual_description: A hand rolling thin red stripes onto a piece of red modelling clay that is placed between two wooden planks.
